title: My family is expecting that I’m living a good life, but I am not, and they are asking details. Should I lie and sound positive? - Quora

response.answer_text: I suggest you break the truth to your parents gently and privately, and decide before hand what your expectations are. Do you expect them to help you? Is there a risk that they will blame you for “bad decisions”, regardless of reality? Are you in a mental space where you can accept help, sometimes more challenging, suggestions or advice? If it’s just a question of clearing up misunderstandings and being honest, then say that first, before you level with them. In general, parents hurt when their child suffers, and it’s hard for us to resist the urge to jump in and fix everything- even when we really can’t. Or you may not want them to. If you DO accept financial help, INSIST on writing down how much they are giving OR lending you. Define it: gift or loan? What are the conditions? When will you start paying it back? They may resist doing this but explain it’ll make you feel better- your pride requires it. Everyone signs, dates it, everyone gets a copy. if your situation changes, revisit this. As you would with a bank, ask to repay more slowly BUT REPAY. Listen, unless you’re in an abusive situation your parents love you and want only good things for you. Thoughtfully, gently open up. It’ll work out. Amy

You might be better served by figuring out what you are doing that prevents you from “living the good life” (by your own estimation, not anyone else's), and making the corrections necessary to make that happen. Lying to your family or yourself will never resolve the issue.
